thread.title: Deerfield Beach Now and Then: A look at city's history - Sun Sentinel
thread.title_full: Deerfield Beach Now and Then: A look at city's history - Sun Sentinel

author: South Florida Sun-Sentinel
title: Deerfield Beach Now and Then: A look at city's history - Sun Sentinel
text:
Deerfield Beach: A Look at History Courtesy/Deerfield Beach Historical Society 
In 1898, C.E. Hunt, a civil engineer for the Florida East Coast Railroad, platted 12 acres between the railroad tracks and the intracoastal waterway and named it Hillsborough after the Earl of Hillsborough. There were initially 20 settlers, 
At the time, the permanent population was about 20. 
In 1898, C.E. Hunt, a civil engineer for the Florida East Coast Railroad, platted 12 acres between the railroad tracks and the intracoastal waterway and named it Hillsborough after the Earl of Hillsborough. There were initially 20 settlers, 
At the time, the permanent population was about 20. (Courtesy/Deerfield Beach Historical Society) See more galleries 
In 1890 the first houses appeared here along the Hillsboro River. Flagler's railroad stretched into Miami a few years later. In 1898 the first post office was built to serve about 20 settlers in Deerfield, named for the deer that grazed along the river. By 1910, the business district centered along Hillsboro Boulevard and Dixie Highway. Produce was the center of the city's economy and African-Americans worked the fields in the segregated city. The town was incorporated in 1925 and there were 1,300 residents. The name changed to Deerfield Beach in 1951 and the city became more tourist-based. By Lisa J. Huriash
